Baden Powell belongs to the small circle of guitarists whose early virtuosity is perfectly combined with a keen sense of harmony. Powell demonstrates this special talent in his slow numbers in particular, in which broken chords are developed like a bud opening out to a blossom.

He guides the listener cautiously through his melodies in that he makes a tiny pause before a harmonic change. Full timbre and lightness are not a question of what is written down on the manuscript but result from a powerful performance, as is shown by the totally un-Brazilian, gentle major-minor key version of the childrenÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s song "Komnt Ein Vogel Geflogen."

Naturally, the wonderfully crafted, animated and bouncy bossas flow along easily. As befits the albumÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s title, the guitar is in the limelight here, driven on, held back, and then propelled forward by the rhythm group. The ballad "Se Todos Fossem Iguais A Voce" is strongly recommended to wet your appetite for the bossa "Na Gafieira Do Vidigal."
